Dan Stromberg wrote:
> There's something I'm not getting about REST.
> We'r=
e supposed to use HTTP verbs like GET, PUT, POST and DELETE.
> But we're al=
so supposed to be avoiding server state, like sessions.
> How can we have a=
 stateless protocol (that is, a protocol in which
> all state is saved in t=
he client, using the REST hierarchy as a
> sort of state machine), that sup=
ports a DELETE operation? Are some
> HTTP verbs more RESTful than others?=
=A0 It seems like PUT, POST and
> DELETE are all about storing state on the=
 server.

Resource state is not the same as application state. The former i=
s generally under the control of servers and the latter should be maintaine=
d by the client using standardized methods (which exchange representations)=
 on uniform identifiers to advance from one application state to another. S=
ee http://www.infoq.com/articles/mark-baker-hypermedia, for example, for a =
more in-depth discussion.


Robert Brewer
